abstract.p: Letters from Dr Maria A Oquendo and Jessica A Lew respond to May 23 article about increasing number of South Koreans who are using Internet to discuss suicide

block.p: Re ''Tracking an Online Trend, and a Route to Suicide'' (Seoul Journal, May 23):
Re ''Tracking an Online Trend, and a Route to Suicide'' (Seoul Journal, May 23):

The devastating effects of suicide are no doubt echoing through the South Korean population. Contagion, be it through the Internet or other informal or formal channels, has been a source of concern, especially in youth. But to ignore the well-known link to psychiatric disorders and to attribute suicide only to psychosocial causes wastes an important opportunity to avoid death for a vulnerable population.
In most countries, 90 percent of all suicide deaths are attributable to a treatable psychiatric condition. There is hope.
Maria A. Oquendo, M.D. New York, May 23, 2007
The writer is a professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia University.

I could not believe that the Korean government's response to the rising suicide rate is to consider making pesticides less lethal and increasing the number of barriers at potential sites of suicide. Why not use those resources to improve awareness of mental illness rather than making it simply more difficult for potential suicide victims to kill themselves?

If people are suicidal, it is more likely that they will find a means by which to end their lives. But if awareness about mental illness is raised and counseling is readily available, not only will these people not be as likely to end their lives, but they also will be more likely to live happy, productive lives.
Jessica A. Lew Scarsdale, N.Y., May 23, 2007
